hook.text: You agree to mow your neighbor's lawn for $50. Shake hands. That's a contractâ€”no paper needed.

buildup.text: A contract is a legally enforceable agreement between two or more parties that creates obligations.

discovery.text: It needs four elements: offer, acceptance, consideration, and mutual assent.

twist.text: Most contracts don't need to be written. Oral contracts are valid for many transactions.

climax.text: But proving an oral contract in court is much harder. Writing creates evidence of the deal.

punchline.text: A promise backed by law. That's a contract.

quiz.question: What four elements form a valid contract?

hook.text: You say 'I'll sell my car for $5,000.' Your friend says 'Deal.' A contract just formed in two seconds.

buildup.text: An offer is a clear proposal to enter a contract. Acceptance is unconditional agreement to those terms.

discovery.text: The offer must be definite enough that a court can determine the terms. Vague promises don't count.

twist.text: A counteroffer kills the original offer. Saying 'I'll pay $4,000' is a rejection, not acceptance.

climax.text: Under the mailbox rule, acceptance is effective when sentâ€”not when the offeror receives it.

punchline.text: One side proposes. The other agrees. That's the spark.

quiz.question: What happens when you make a counteroffer?

topics.title: Consideration: The Price of a Promise

hook.text: Your uncle promises you $10,000 as a gift. He changes his mind. You can't sueâ€”there was no consideration.

buildup.text: Consideration is something of value exchanged between parties: money, services, a promise to act or refrain.

discovery.text: Both sides must give something. A one-sided promise with nothing in return is a gift, not a contract.

twist.text: Courts don't judge adequacy. Selling a house for $1 is valid consideration if both parties agreed freely.

climax.text: Past consideration doesn't count either. Paying someone for a favor they already did isn't enforceable.

punchline.text: No exchange, no contract. Consideration is the deal's engine.

quiz.question: Why is a gift promise not enforceable as a contract?

hook.text: A 16-year-old signs a contract to buy a luxury car. He can return it and walk away. The dealer can't.

buildup.text: Capacity means the legal ability to enter a contract. Minors, mentally impaired, and intoxicated persons may lack it.

discovery.text: Minors can void most contracts at willâ€”called disaffirmanceâ€”until a reasonable time after turning 18.

twist.text: Exceptions exist: contracts for necessities like food, shelter, and medical care bind minors.

climax.text: Mental incapacity voids a contract only if the person couldn't understand the nature of the agreement.

punchline.text: The law protects those who can't fully protect themselves.

quiz.question: What can a minor generally do with a contract they signed?
options: Disaffirm it before or shortly after turning 18

hook.text: You verbally agree to sell your house. The buyer shows up with cash. Too badâ€”land deals must be in writing.

buildup.text: The Statute of Frauds requires certain contracts to be written to be enforceable.

discovery.text: It covers land sales, contracts lasting over a year, goods over $500, and promises to pay another's debt.

twist.text: Part performance can override the rule. If you already moved in and paid, a court may enforce the oral deal.

climax.text: The writing doesn't need to be formalâ€”even a napkin works if it has the essential terms and a signature.

punchline.text: Some deals need ink. The Statute of Frauds says which ones.

quiz.question: Which contract must be in writing under the Statute of Frauds?
options: Hiring a babysitter for an evening

hook.text: Your lease says rent is $1,500 a month. It doesn't say the landlord must provide running water. But they must.

buildup.text: Express terms are explicitly stated by the parties. Implied terms are read in by law or custom.

discovery.text: Courts imply terms to fill gaps: good faith dealing, reasonable time for performance, and fitness for purpose.

twist.text: Implied terms can override what the contract is silent aboutâ€”but rarely override express terms.

climax.text: The UCC implies a warranty of merchantability in every sale by a merchant, even if the contract is silent.

punchline.text: What the contract says matters. What it doesn't say can matter more.

quiz.question: What are implied terms in a contract?
options: Terms the parties explicitly agreed to
Terms read in by law or custom

hook.text: You signed a contract. Now you claim the seller verbally promised something extra. The court won't hear it.

buildup.text: The parol evidence rule bars prior or contemporaneous oral agreements that contradict a written contract.

discovery.text: The rationale: once parties put their deal in writing, the document should be the final word.

twist.text: Exceptions exist for fraud, mistake, ambiguity, or showing the contract isn't the complete agreement.

climax.text: Integration clausesâ€”'this is the entire agreement'â€”make it even harder to introduce outside evidence.

punchline.text: If it's not in the contract, it might as well not exist.

quiz.question: What does the parol evidence rule prevent?
options: Using prior oral agreements to contradict a written contract

hook.text: You'll buy a houseâ€”if the inspection passes. That 'if' is a condition precedent. No pass, no deal.

buildup.text: Conditions are events that must occur (or not occur) before a party's duty to perform is triggered.

discovery.text: A condition precedent must happen first. Concurrent conditions happen simultaneously. Subsequent ones end a duty.

twist.text: Courts prefer to interpret ambiguous terms as promises, not conditionsâ€”breach of a promise gives a remedy.

climax.text: Failure of a condition precedent excuses performance entirely. No one breachedâ€”the deal just doesn't activate.

punchline.text: Conditions are the switches. They turn obligations on and off.

quiz.question: What is a condition precedent?
options: An event that ends a contract
An event that must occur before a duty to perform arises

hook.text: A landlord technically followed the lease but made the tenant's life miserable to force them out. That's bad faith.

buildup.text: Every contract includes an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under US law.

discovery.text: It means neither party should do anything to destroy the other's right to receive the contract's benefits.

twist.text: Good faith doesn't require generosity. It prevents using the contract as a weapon against the other party.

climax.text: Courts use it to police creative loophole exploitationâ€”the letter of the contract vs. its spirit.

punchline.text: Contracts require honesty, not just compliance.

quiz.question: What does the implied covenant of good faith prevent?
options: Destroying the other party's right to the contract's benefits

hook.text: An insurance policy had a vague clause. The insurer wrote it. The court ruled against the insurer.

buildup.text: Contra proferentem means ambiguous terms are interpreted against the party who drafted them.

discovery.text: The logic: the drafter had the power to be clear. If they weren't, they bear the risk of ambiguity.

twist.text: It's most powerful in consumer contracts where one side had no ability to negotiate or clarify terms.

climax.text: Courts use it as a last resortâ€”only after other interpretation methods fail to resolve the ambiguity.

punchline.text: Write it vaguely, lose the argument. Clarity is self-defense.

quiz.question: What does contra proferentem mean?
options: Ambiguity is interpreted against the drafter
Both parties share the risk equally

hook.text: A builder finishes a house but uses the wrong brand of pipe. Can the buyer refuse to pay entirely?

buildup.text: A material breach is a failure so significant that it undermines the entire purpose of the contract.

discovery.text: A minor breach is a small deviation that doesn't destroy the contract's value. The deal continues.

twist.text: A material breach lets the injured party cancel the contract. A minor breach only allows a claim for damages.

climax.text: Courts weigh how much benefit the injured party received and whether the breach can be cured.

punchline.text: Not all breaches break the deal. The severity determines the remedy.

quiz.question: What can the injured party do after a material breach?

hook.text: A supplier tells you two months early: 'We won't deliver.' You don't have to waitâ€”you can act now.

buildup.text: Anticipatory repudiation occurs when a party clearly indicates they won't perform before the deadline arrives.

discovery.text: The innocent party can immediately treat it as a breach, sue for damages, or seek a substitute deal.

twist.text: The repudiating party can retract their refusalâ€”but only if the other side hasn't already relied on the repudiation.

climax.text: This doctrine prevents waste: why wait for a deadline everyone knows will be missed?

punchline.text: Saying 'I won't do it' is just as much a breach as not doing it.

quiz.question: What is anticipatory repudiation?
options: Declaring in advance you won't perform

hook.text: A painter finished 95% of the job perfectly but missed one small wall. Must the homeowner pay nothing?

buildup.text: Substantial performance means the party performed almost everything required, with only trivial deviations.

discovery.text: Under this doctrine, the performing party can still collect paymentâ€”minus the cost to fix the deficiency.

twist.text: It only applies if the breach was not willful. Deliberately cutting corners kills the defense.

climax.text: Jacob & Youngs v. Kent: a builder used equivalent pipe instead of the specified brand. The court allowed payment.

punchline.text: Close enough can be good enoughâ€”if the shortfall is honest and minor.

quiz.question: When does substantial performance NOT apply?

hook.text: You rented a balcony to watch a royal parade. The parade was canceled. Do you still owe rent?

buildup.text: Impossibility excuses performance when an unforeseen event makes it truly impossible to fulfill the contract.

discovery.text: Frustration of purpose applies when performance is possible but the reason for the contract has been destroyed.

twist.text: COVID-19 triggered thousands of frustration claims. Courts split on whether a pandemic was truly 'unforeseen.'

climax.text: The event must be beyond both parties' control and not something the contract allocated risk for.

punchline.text: When the world changes, contracts sometimes can't keep up.

quiz.question: What does frustration of purpose mean?
options: The main purpose of the contract has been destroyed
One party is frustrated with the terms

hook.text: Your parents buy you a life insurance policy. You didn't sign anything, but you can sue if the insurer won't pay.

buildup.text: A third-party beneficiary is someone who benefits from a contract between two other parties.

discovery.text: Intended beneficiaries can enforce the contract. Incidental beneficiariesâ€”who benefit by accidentâ€”cannot.

twist.text: Once the beneficiary's rights vestâ€”usually when they learn of and rely on the contractâ€”the parties can't modify it.

climax.text: Lawrence v. Fox (1859) established that third-party beneficiaries have enforceable rights in American law.

punchline.text: You don't have to sign a contract to benefit from one.

quiz.question: Who can enforce a contract as a third-party beneficiary?
options: Anyone who benefits in any way

hook.text: Sign this contract or I'll destroy your business. You sign. That contract is voidableâ€”you were coerced.

buildup.text: Duress means one party was forced to agree through threats, violence, or wrongful pressure.

discovery.text: Undue influence is subtler: exploiting a position of trustâ€”like a caretaker pressuring an elderly person.

twist.text: Economic duress counts too. Threatening to breach a critical contract unless terms are renegotiated can qualify.

climax.text: The victim can void the contract, but must act promptly. Waiting too long implies acceptance of the terms.

punchline.text: Consent under pressure isn't real consent.

quiz.question: What is the difference between duress and undue influence?
options: Duress uses threats; undue influence exploits trust
Duress only applies to physical force

hook.text: A payday lender charges 400% interest to a desperate borrower. A court can refuse to enforce that deal.

buildup.text: Unconscionability lets courts void contracts that are so unfair they shock the conscience.

discovery.text: Two types: procedural (unfair processâ€”no real choice) and substantive (unfair termsâ€”outrageously one-sided).

twist.text: Most courts require both types. Unfair terms alone aren't enough if the process was transparent.

climax.text: It's a safety valve. Courts use it sparingly to prevent extreme exploitation, not to rewrite bad deals.

punchline.text: Freedom to contract has limits. Exploitation is one of them.

quiz.question: What are the two types of unconscionability?

hook.text: Both buyer and seller thought the painting was a copy. It was an original worth millions. Who keeps it?

buildup.text: A mutual mistake about a basic assumption of the contract can make it voidable by the harmed party.

discovery.text: Sherwood v. Walker: both parties thought a cow was barren. She was pregnant. The court voided the sale.

twist.text: A unilateral mistakeâ€”only one party is wrongâ€”usually isn't enough to void the contract unless the other party knew.

climax.text: The mistake must go to the essence of the deal, not just a bad judgment about value or market conditions.

punchline.text: When both sides are wrong about what they're trading, the deal can unravel.

quiz.question: When can a mutual mistake void a contract?
options: When both parties share a mistake about a basic assumption

hook.text: A seller says the house has no termites. You find them everywhere. That lie makes the contract voidable.

buildup.text: Misrepresentation is a false statement of fact that induces the other party to enter a contract.

discovery.text: Fraud requires intent to deceive. Innocent misrepresentationâ€”an honest mistakeâ€”is also a defense, with fewer remedies.

twist.text: Silence can be misrepresentation too. If you know about a hidden defect and a duty to disclose exists, silence is a lie.

climax.text: The victim can void the contract and, in fraud cases, also recover punitive damages.

punchline.text: Contracts built on lies don't stand. Truth is the foundation.

quiz.question: What separates fraud from innocent misrepresentation?

hook.text: You hire someone to commit a crime and they don't follow through. Can you sue for breach? Absolutely not.

buildup.text: Contracts with illegal purposes are void from the start. Courts won't enforce them for either party.

discovery.text: This includes contracts for illegal services, agreements that violate public policy, and unlicensed work.

twist.text: If only part of a contract is illegal, courts may sever the bad part and enforce the rest.

climax.text: Neither party can recover under an illegal contract. The law leaves them where it found them.

punchline.text: An illegal deal is no deal at all.

quiz.question: What happens to a contract with an illegal purpose?
options: Only the illegal party is penalized
It's void and unenforceable for both parties

hook.text: A supplier breaches and you lose $50,000 in profits. The court orders them to pay exactly that amount.

buildup.text: Expectation damages put the injured party in the position they'd be in if the contract was performed.

discovery.text: They include lost profits, cost of replacement, and any additional expenses caused by the breach.

twist.text: But you must mitigate: if you could have found a cheaper substitute and didn't, your damages are reduced.

climax.text: Hadley v. Baxendale limits damages to those foreseeable at the time of contracting. Surprise losses don't count.

punchline.text: The goal is to make you wholeâ€”not to punish the breacher.

quiz.question: What do expectation damages aim to do?
options: Put the injured party where they'd be if the contract was performed
Return both parties to pre-contract status

hook.text: You contracted to buy a unique painting. The seller refuses. Money can't replace it. The court orders delivery.

buildup.text: Specific performance is an equitable remedy: a court order compelling the breaching party to do what they promised.

discovery.text: It's only granted when monetary damages are inadequateâ€”typically for unique items, land, or rare goods.

twist.text: Courts almost never order specific performance for personal services. Forcing someone to work raises freedom concerns.

climax.text: Land contracts are the classic case. Every parcel is legally unique, so money is never a perfect substitute.

punchline.text: When money isn't enough, courts order action.

quiz.question: When do courts typically grant specific performance?
options: When the subject is unique and damages are inadequate

hook.text: A construction contract says $1,000 per day for delays. The project runs over. The clause kicks in automatically.

buildup.text: Liquidated damages are pre-agreed amounts that parties set in the contract for specific breaches.

discovery.text: They're valid if the amount is a reasonable estimate of anticipated harm and actual damages would be hard to calculate.

twist.text: If the amount is grossly disproportionate, courts treat it as a penaltyâ€”and penalties are unenforceable.

climax.text: The line between liquidated damages and penalties is thin. Reasonableness at the time of contracting is the key test.

punchline.text: Agree on the price of breach in advance. Just keep it reasonable.

quiz.question: When are liquidated damages enforceable?
options: When they reasonably estimate anticipated harm

hook.text: You discover the car you bought was in a flood. You want to undo the entire deal. That's rescission.

buildup.text: Rescission cancels the contract and returns both parties to their pre-contract positions.

discovery.text: Restitution requires returning any benefits received. You give back the car; the seller refunds your money.

twist.text: Rescission is available for fraud, mutual mistake, or failure of considerationâ€”not just any breach.

climax.text: You must act promptly. Using the item extensively after discovering the defect can waive your right to rescind.

punchline.text: Rescission rewinds the deal. Restitution makes it fair.

quiz.question: What does rescission do to a contract?
options: Cancels it and restores both parties to their original positions

hook.text: Your employer promised a pension. You stayed 20 years. They revoke it. No contract, but a court may enforce it anyway.

buildup.text: Promissory estoppel enforces promises that lack consideration when someone reasonably relied on them.

discovery.text: Requirements: a clear promise, reasonable reliance by the promisee, and injustice if the promise isn't enforced.

twist.text: It's a substitute for consideration, not a replacement for all contract elements. Courts use it narrowly.

climax.text: Damages are often limited to reliance lossesâ€”what you spent because of the promiseâ€”not full expectation damages.

punchline.text: When a promise changes someone's life, breaking it has consequences.

quiz.question: What does promissory estoppel substitute for?

hook.text: You clicked 'I agree' without reading 50 pages of terms. You just entered a binding contract.

buildup.text: Clickwrap agreements require users to click a button agreeing to terms. Courts generally enforce them.

discovery.text: Browsewrap agreements say 'by using this site, you agree.' No click neededâ€”and courts are more skeptical.

twist.text: The key issue is notice: did the user have a reasonable opportunity to read the terms before agreeing?

climax.text: Buried terms that are surprising or unconscionable may still be struck down, even in clickwrap agreements.

punchline.text: Clicking 'agree' is the new handshake. Reading the terms is the new diligence.

quiz.question: Why are browsewrap agreements harder to enforce than clickwrap?
options: Users may not have reasonable notice of the terms

hook.text: A pandemic shuts down the world. Companies everywhere reach for the same clause: force majeure.

buildup.text: Force majeure clauses excuse performance when extraordinary events beyond the parties' control occur.

discovery.text: Common triggers: natural disasters, wars, epidemics, and government orders that make performance impossible.

twist.text: The clause must specifically list the event type. Many pre-2020 contracts didn't include 'pandemic,' creating disputes.

climax.text: Post-COVID, lawyers draft these clauses much more carefullyâ€”and they're in virtually every major contract.

punchline.text: When the unthinkable happens, the clause you wrote matters most.

quiz.question: What do force majeure clauses do?

hook.text: You quit your job and start a competing business. Your former employer suesâ€”you signed a non-compete.

buildup.text: Non-compete agreements restrict employees from working for competitors for a set period after leaving.

discovery.text: Courts enforce them only if they're reasonable in scope, duration, and geography.

twist.text: The FTC proposed banning most non-competes nationwide, arguing they suppress wages and limit worker freedom.

climax.text: California already bans them entirely. Other states are following. The legal landscape is shifting fast.

punchline.text: Protecting business secrets is fair. Trapping workers isn't.

quiz.question: What must a non-compete agreement be to be enforceable?
options: Reasonable in scope, duration, and geography

hook.text: A contract executes itself: payment releases automatically when goods arrive. No lawyers needed. Or so they say.

buildup.text: Smart contracts are self-executing code on a blockchain that automatically enforces agreed terms.

discovery.text: They eliminate intermediaries: escrow, banks, and even some legal processes become unnecessary.

twist.text: But code has bugs. The 2016 DAO hack exploited a smart contract flaw, draining $60 million in cryptocurrency.

climax.text: Legal systems are struggling to classify smart contracts. Are they contracts? Software? Something entirely new?

punchline.text: Code can execute a deal. Only law can make it fair.

quiz.question: What is a smart contract?

topics.title: Arbitration Clauses and Access to Courts

hook.text: You want to sue a company, but the contract says all disputes go to arbitration. You never noticed that clause.

buildup.text: Arbitration clauses require disputes to be resolved by a private arbitrator instead of a court.

discovery.text: Companies favor arbitration: it's faster, private, and often less expensive than litigation.

twist.text: Critics say forced arbitration strips consumers and employees of their right to a jury trial and class actions.

climax.text: The Supreme Court has broadly upheld arbitration clauses, even in consumer and employment contracts.

punchline.text: The fine print can decide whereâ€”and howâ€”justice happens.

quiz.question: What do arbitration clauses require?
options: Disputes go to a private arbitrator instead of court
